verses.kjv: And when it was determined that we should sail into Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners unto one named Julius, a centurion of Augustus’ band.
verses.ct: Once the decision was made for us to sail to Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were handed over to a centurion named Julius, who belonged to the Imperial Regiment.

verses.kjv: And entering into a ship of Adramyttium, we launched, meaning to sail by the coasts of Asia; one Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.
verses.ct: We boarded a ship from Adramyttium that was headed along the coast of Asia, and we set sail. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, came with us.

verses.kjv: And the next day we touched at Sidon. And Julius courteously entreated Paul, and gave him liberty to go unto his friends to refresh himself.
verses.ct: The next day we docked at Sidon. Julius treated Paul kindly and allowed him to visit his friends so they could take care of his needs.

verses.kjv: And when we had launched from thence, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.
verses.ct: From there we put out to sea and sailed on the sheltered side of Cyprus because the winds were blowing against us.

verses.kjv: And when we had sailed over the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.
verses.ct: After crossing the open sea off the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we arrived at Myra in Lycia.

verses.kjv: And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing into Italy; and he put us therein.
verses.ct: There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship bound for Italy and transferred us onto it.

verses.kjv: And when we had sailed slowly many days, and scarce were come over against Cnidus, the wind not suffering us, we sailed under Crete, over against Salmone;
verses.ct: We made slow progress for many days and had difficulty reaching a point near Cnidus. Since the wind wouldn't let us continue on course, we sailed along the sheltered side of Crete, passing Salmone.

verses.kjv: And, hardly passing it, came unto a place which is called The fair havens; nigh whereunto was the city of Lasea.
verses.ct: We barely managed to get past it and arrived at a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.

verses.kjv: Now when much time was spent, and when sailing was now dangerous, because the fast was now already past, Paul admonished them,
verses.ct: A great deal of time had been lost, and sailing had become dangerous because the Day of Atonement fast had already passed. So Paul warned them,

verses.kjv: And said unto them, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage will be with hurt and much damage, not only of the lading and ship, but also of our lives.
verses.ct: "Men, I can see that this voyage is going to end in disaster and heavy loss — not just to the cargo and the ship, but to our own lives as well."

verses.kjv: Nevertheless the centurion believed the master and the owner of the ship, more than those things which were spoken by Paul.
verses.ct: But the centurion trusted the ship's pilot and its owner more than what Paul said.

verses.kjv: And because the haven was not commodious to winter in, the more part advised to depart thence also, if by any means they might attain to Phenice, and there to winter; which is an haven of Crete, and lieth toward the south west and north west.
verses.ct: Since the harbor wasn't suitable for spending the winter, the majority decided to sail on, hoping to reach Phoenix — a harbor in Crete that faces both southwest and northwest — and spend the winter there.

verses.kjv: And when the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, loosing thence, they sailed close by Crete.
verses.ct: When a gentle south wind began to blow, they thought they had exactly what they needed. So they pulled up anchor and sailed close along the coast of Crete.

verses.kjv: But not long after there arose against it a tempestuous wind, called Euroclydon.
verses.ct: But before long, a violent wind called the Northeaster swept down from the island.

verses.kjv: And when the ship was caught, and could not bear up into the wind, we let her drive.
verses.ct: The ship was caught by the storm and couldn't head into the wind, so we gave up and let it be driven along.

verses.kjv: And running under a certain island which is called Clauda, we had much work to come by the boat:
verses.ct: As we passed on the sheltered side of a small island called Clauda, we struggled to secure the lifeboat.

verses.kjv: Which when they had taken up, they used helps, undergirding the ship; and, fearing lest they should fall into the quicksands, strake sail, and so were driven.
verses.ct: After hoisting it aboard, the crew used ropes to reinforce the hull of the ship. Afraid of being driven onto the sandbars of Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor and let the ship drift.

verses.kjv: And we being exceedingly tossed with a tempest, the next day they lightened the ship;
verses.ct: The storm battered us so violently that the next day the crew began throwing cargo overboard.

verses.kjv: And the third day we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship.
verses.ct: On the 3rd day, we threw the ship's equipment overboard with our own hands.

verses.kjv: And when neither sun nor stars in many days appeared, and no small tempest lay on us, all hope that we should be saved was then taken away.
verses.ct: For many days neither the sun nor the stars were visible, and the fierce storm continued to rage. Eventually we gave up all hope of surviving.

verses.kjv: But after long abstinence Paul stood forth in the midst of them, and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me, and not have loosed from Crete, and to have gained this harm and loss.
verses.ct: After everyone had gone a long time without eating, Paul stood up among them and said, "Men, you should have listened to me and not sailed from Crete. You would have avoided all this damage and loss.

verses.kjv: And now I exhort you to be of good cheer: for there shall be no loss of any man’s life among you, but of the ship.
verses.ct: But now I urge you to take courage, because not a single one of you will die — only the ship will be lost.

verses.kjv: For there stood by me this night the angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve,
verses.ct: Last night an angel of the God I belong to and serve stood beside me

verses.kjv: Saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must be brought before Caesar: and, lo, God hath given thee all them that sail with thee.
verses.ct: and said, 'Don't be afraid, Paul. You must stand trial before Caesar. And look — God has graciously granted you the lives of everyone sailing with you.'

verses.kjv: Wherefore, sirs, be of good cheer: for I believe God, that it shall be even as it was told me.
verses.ct: So take courage, men! I trust God that everything will happen exactly as he told me.

verses.kjv: Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island.
verses.ct: However, we will run aground on some island."

verses.kjv: But when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven up and down in Adria, about midnight the shipmen deemed that they drew near to some country;
verses.ct: On the 14th night, as we were being tossed around in the Adriatic Sea, around midnight the sailors sensed that we were approaching land.

verses.kjv: And sounded, and found it twenty fathoms: and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again, and found it fifteen fathoms.
verses.ct: They took a depth measurement and found it was 120 feet. A short distance later they measured again and found it was 90 feet.

verses.kjv: Then fearing lest we should have fallen upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day.
verses.ct: Afraid that we might crash against the rocks, they dropped 4 anchors from the back of the ship and prayed for daylight to come.

verses.kjv: And as the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship,
verses.ct: The sailors tried to escape from the ship by lowering the lifeboat into the sea, pretending they were going to drop anchors from the front of the ship.

verses.kjv: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
verses.ct: But Paul told the centurion and the soldiers, "Unless these men stay on the ship, you cannot be saved."

verses.kjv: Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.
verses.ct: So the soldiers cut the ropes holding the lifeboat and let it drift away.

verses.kjv: And while the day was coming on, Paul besought them all to take meat, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting, having taken nothing.
verses.ct: Just before dawn, Paul urged everyone to eat something. He said, "For 14 days now you've been in constant suspense and have gone without food, eating nothing.

verses.kjv: Wherefore I pray you to take some meat: for this is for your health: for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.
verses.ct: So I'm asking you to eat something. You need it to survive. Not a single hair from anyone's head will be lost."

verses.kjv: And when he had thus spoken, he took bread, and gave thanks to God in presence of them all: and when he had broken it, he began to eat.
verses.ct: After saying this, he took some bread, thanked God in front of everyone, broke it, and began to eat.

verses.kjv: Then were they all of good cheer, and they also took some meat.
verses.ct: This encouraged all of them, and they ate some food as well.

verses.kjv: And we were in all in the ship two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.
verses.ct: There were 276 of us on the ship in total.

verses.kjv: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea.
verses.ct: After everyone had eaten their fill, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain overboard into the sea.

verses.kjv: And when it was day, they knew not the land: but they discovered a certain creek with a shore, into the which they were minded, if it were possible, to thrust in the ship.
verses.ct: When daylight came, they didn't recognize the coastline, but they spotted a bay with a sandy beach and decided to try to run the ship onto it if possible.

verses.kjv: And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves unto the sea, and loosed the rudder bands, and hoised up the mainsail to the wind, and made toward shore.
verses.ct: They cut the anchors loose and left them in the sea, untied the ropes holding the rudders, raised the front sail to catch the wind, and headed for the beach.

verses.kjv: And falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the forepart stuck fast, and remained unmoveable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.
verses.ct: But the ship hit a sandbar where two currents met and ran aground. The front of the ship stuck fast and wouldn't move, while the back was being smashed apart by the pounding waves.

verses.kjv: And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape.
verses.ct: The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners to prevent any of them from swimming away and escaping.

verses.kjv: But the centurion, willing to save Paul, kept them from their purpose; and commanded that they which could swim should cast themselves first into the sea, and get to land:
verses.ct: But the centurion wanted to save Paul, so he stopped them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and make for shore.

verses.kjv: And the rest, some on boards, and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to pass, that they escaped all safe to land.
verses.ct: The rest grabbed planks or other pieces of the wrecked ship. In this way, everyone made it safely to land.
